seg.output:
I reported to our people what is threatened to the brothers in Bremgarten by the Imontani, as told by Sebastian, especially to the Pandareto Pastor, now sending a deputy to the four last elections.When they had not understood a word, yet, by reading the articles of the elections, commonly called den abscheid, they learned that same thing which Sebastian had reported.The letters of the Bremgartens were read, by which they had subjected themselves to the Papistic Quinquepago, likewise what the pious fear was proposed to the diaconists.Thus it was committed to the same deputies, namely Stürler and Pandareto Pastor, to admonish the Quinquepago to desist from their institution.If they should not want to, let the matter be settled by the forensic right.So much we have done for your admonition and as much as we could.
Therefore, I cannot answer your letters separately in my spare time.I have only admonished that, while you go with Pellican to do good to these brothers with the gifts, to which both are abundantly testified, which came out into the light.It shall be looked to by both of them, that you show more of your expertise in the scriptures to the unlearned and to those who do not understand languages, who minster the word with pious zeal, than to the learned, since love alone builds up and knows to be all things to all, but knowledge only puffs up.Both shall strive for brevity, yet in such a manner, that either moderately pious or learned shall soon smell what the spirit of the Lord in the simplicity of the scriptures wishes, what therefore we should be taught and with what opportunity all should be spread to the people.

seg.output: Therefore, in order to respond to your letters, each one in particular, I am not able to do so in my free time. I will only caution you to continue to be generous to those brothers with the same gifts which both of them have been abundantly blessed with and have come to light. It should be noted that you should show greater care towards those who are not learned and lack knowledge of languages yet strive in pious zeal to serve the word of God, with your skill in the scriptures, than what you may show the learned, since charity alone builds and knows that all things are possible for all. Both strive for brevity, however, in such a way that even those who are moderately pious or learned can immediately sense what the Lord desires with the simplicity of the scriptures, as well as what we should be taught and on what occasions it should all be spread to the masses. These are the things which many have desired for many years. May the Lord therefore provide so that you can progress most happily. Zuinglius, our fellow, detested publishing more commentaries, so that those attached to them would not be delayed from the reading of the scriptures without judgment. But since it is not given to everyone to go to Corinth and the majority is delayed from the reading of the scriptures because it appears impassable without a guide, continue, continue, and share with me as far as each one is able to reach.

In response to your letters, I cannot take the time to answer each one individually. I can only advise you to continue to be generous to both Pellicanus and his brothers with the same gifts that they have both been endowed with, which have come to light. It is important for both of them to show that they are as devoted to the ignorant and those who do not understand languages, as they are to the wise, by using their knowledge to help those who are studying the scriptures with great piety, since charity alone builds and knows how to be all things to all people, while knowledge puffs up. Each of them should strive for brevity, yet in such a way that those who are moderately pious or wise can quickly understand what the Spirit of the Lord intends by the simplicity of the Scriptures, what is to be taught, and on what occasion everything should be spread to the public. All these things have already been desired by many for many years. May the Lord grant that you may continue with the greatest success. Our Zwingli was horrified at the idea of publishing many commentaries, so that, by being absorbed by them, we would be hindered from reading the Scriptures. But since not everyone is able to go to Corinth, and the majority are hindered from the reading of the Scriptures because they seem inaccessible without a guide, continue, continue, and share with me what each one has achieved. For I do not cease to remind the brethren to ask this from God and from yourselves.
How can it be that the best way of studying would be displeasing? But in this I am hindered, that it is not possible to divide the days and hours amidst the tumult of all affairs and business. I am forced to claim the morning hours for the second, fourth and sixth days of the week for the consistory, and it is not enough to assign them to this, for when I return home, I am forced to be the exposed advisor to all the peasants, whatever ever was done in the consistory. For it is a custom with us that each one should explain his own matters. There are then three sermons to be preached each. To which when I have devoted my mind, I am sometimes forced to steal the night hours. You judge how much time is left for the ordinary reading of the Scriptures, or for the study of languages or history.

seg.output:
What is the best way to organize studies, and how could it be displeasing? But I fail in this because, due to the chaos of all things and affairs, it is not possible to divide days and hours. I am forced to reserve the morning hours for the second, fourth and sixth days in the consistory, and it is not enough to have assigned them to this place; when I return home, I have to be exposed as a consultor to all, even to the rustics, whatever they have had to do in the consistory. For it is our custom that everyone should make known his own affairs. There are then three conferences each of which I must hold. When I have devoted my attention to them, I am sometimes forced to steal away some of the night hours. You judge how much time is left for the regular reading of the Scriptures, or for the study of languages or of history. I pass over the care of the churches, which so distracts me, requiring so many letters, that sometimes my spirit and mind fail me, not to say words. If therefore you have anything by which you can help me so overwhelmed, consult it.
Bertram's booklet, read from the beginning, pleased Farello so much that he kept it for himself. If Froschouwer has more, let him send two or three which I will pay for. Of predestination, such as makes one miserable, I have read, and at first sight they could not displease me. But they are not yet so examined and judged by me, that I can answer them with a judgment. Yet I will answer as soon as possible, after I have returned home from the chapters. Sebastian will return his and all the rest. He is very highly recommended to us.
Farewell, dearest Heinric, and continue to love me as you have taken me in commendation, nor cease.
Our Lupulus has departed this life.
May 5th.
Your, though very small, Berch. H.
To Heinric Bullinger, his dearest brother.

seg.output: I reported to our people what Sebastian had said about the threats made to the brothers in Bremgarten by the Imontani, especially to the Pandarete Pastor, who is now a representative at the four most recent elections. When they hadn't heard a word, however, they learned the same thing that Sebastian had reported after reading the articles of the elections, commonly called den abscheid. The letters of the Bremgartens were read, in which they had dedicated themselves to the Quinquepagico papism, as well as what the pious feared, which was proposed by the diacosiis. Hence it was entrusted to the same representatives, namely Stürler and Pandarete Pastor, to warn the Quinquepagos to dissuade them from the institution. If they refuse, the matter should be settled in court. As much as we could do, we did for your instruction. Therefore, it is not possible to respond to your letters one by one in my spare time. I would only warn that, when you go with Pellicano, you should continue to benefit those same brothers with the gifts of which both are abundantly gifted, which have come to light. It should be observed by both that you are more generous to the unlearned and those who do not know languages, but who preach the word with pious zeal, than to the learned, as charity alone builds and knows that all things are possible for all, but knowledge puffs up. Both strive for brevity, however, in such a way that even moderately pious or learned people soon perceive what the spirit of the Lord wants with the simplicity of the scriptures, what should therefore be taught to us and in what way all should be spread to the public.

In response to your letters, it is not possible to reply to each one in detail. I would advise you to keep helping both Pellicanus and his brothers with the gifts which everyone knows they have both been given generously. It is something to be taken into account that you should help the less educated and those who don't know the language, with your expertise in the scriptures, as much as you should show your expertise towards those who are educated. For charity alone builds up, and knowledge puffs up. Both of you strive for brevity, yet in such a way that those who are at least moderately pious or educated can soon realise what the Spirit of the Lord wants in the simplicity of the scriptures, and what should thus be taught to us, and by what occasions everything should be spread out to the people. These are things which many have desired for many years. So may the Lord provide, so that you may continue in the most felicitous way. Our Zuinglius disapproved of publishing many commentaries, so that, being devoted to them, we would not be delayed from reading the scriptures. But since it is not given to all to go to Corinth, and the greatest part is delayed from the reading of the scriptures, since it seems inaccessible without a guide, go on, go on, and share with me whatever each one has brought to. For I do not cease to remind the brothers, so that they may obtain it from God and from you.
How could one possibly dislike the best way of studying? But I am lacking in this, that it is not permissible to divide the days and hours in this way through the tumult of all affairs and businesses. I am forced to claim the morning hours for the second, fourth and sixth fairs in the consistory, and it is not enough that I have placed them there, for when I return home, I am forced to be an exposed advisor to all the rustics, whatever they may have had to do in the consistory. It is also our custom here, that everyone presents his own affairs to each one. There are then three sermons to be made to each one. To which, when I give my attention, I am sometimes forced to steal away the night hours. You judge how much time is left for the ordinary reading of the scriptures, or for the study of languages or history.

seg.output: Concerning the best way of studying, how could one not be pleased? But I am at a loss for how to divide the days and hours between all the tasks and activities. I am forced to claim the morning hours for the second, fourth and sixth days of the week in the council chamber, and when I return home I am also obligated to be an open adviser to all the rustics about all the things that ever took place in the council chamber. That is our custom, that each person explains his own affairs. Three sermons have to be given by each person after that. When I give my attention to these, sometimes I am forced to steal away the night hours. You can judge how much time is left over for the regular reading of the scriptures, languages or history. I don't mention the care of the churches, which distracts me so much and demands so many letters that sometimes my spirit and mind are lacking, not to mention words. If you have anything that can help me out of this overwhelming situation, do advise.
